ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course enabled me to apply all of the skills I developed over the course of my time at Yale including regional analysis, quantitative reasoning and international relations theory. Additionally, the Capstone project was a phenomenal opportunity to refine my experience working on a team and learning to add value in different ways. After having completed this project, I feel much more confident in my understanding of the military, great power competition, and the international stage at large.

The knowledge, skills, and insights developed in this course were not only about the academic material--learning about national security interests and great power competition--but also about professionalism in general. This course was really valuable in teaching me client-management and team-management skills. Though I would not have chosen this course to be over Zoom, I will admit that, more so than any other class, this course taught me about group and professional dynamics in a virtual setting, which I believe are valuable insights when entering the workforce next year.

I learned about US military strategy; US SOCOM and its main divisions/functions; and a specific country whose allegiance concerning the United States is uncertain. I developed skills in cleaning and organizing data and model building/analysis.

1) I learned the fundamentals of strategy, helping me to scaffold decision-making in my own life. 
2) I learned about the process of consulting for a high-powered client. I learned that sometimes, the best consulting advice is not the "correct" advice, but the useful advice that the client  finds helpful where they are. I learned about how to determine when this is the case.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was my best course experience at Yale. It provided students with an incredibly engaging topic with lots of flexibility on how to approach it. Colonel Erfourth also brought in a series of experts to work with us which proved invaluable both for our learning and for the quality of our deliverable. There are virtually no ways in which I could imagine improving this course. For next year, I would suggest removing individual assignments on the syllabus just as we did this time around to allow students more time to work on the final product. This change was incredibly helpful to all of us and I think it will be beneficial to students in the future.

Strengths of the course: 
There were so many strengths of this course! For example, I thought the organization from the get-go was really phenomenal. It really set the group up for success. Similarly, I think meeting in August and doing most of the readings during the summer was really smart. It helped balance our the work throughout the semester. 

Weaknesses of the course:
The only criticism that I have of this course was the heavy emphasis on planning at the beginning. To be clear, I think this planning was very helpful for the most part, and essential to producing our report. That being said, I do think the level of planning was a little excessive and maybe wasted time toward the end. In order to improve this course, I would suggest planning to take up only a third of the total time. If the course was taught over 3 months, I would suggest the planning phase take up only a month (September) and then there should be a transition to begin the research for the deliverables at the start of the second month (October).

The strengths of this course were the opportunities to engage with professionals with vast experience in military operations and planning. While most students came to the course with 0 understanding of the US military/military strategy&operations, our professor, as well as the other professionals with whom we worked, spent numerous, valuable hrs catching us up to speed on the workings of the various institutions. This time was extremely valuable; in some cases, we not only spent our time together discussing questions but also were able to seek direct feedback on our work products. The main weakness of the course was that our pre-session work was unproductive. One of the main problems our team faced was a lack of alignment regarding the assumptions undergirding our work. As the team grew more acquainted over the course of the semester, it became more clear that everyone brought in different perspectives that shaped how they approached the project. For example, some members of the group were hard realists; others were liberalists; etc. Because we failed to align on fundamental assumptions earlier in the semester, our group ended up wasting time on surface level disagreements that could have otherwise been resolved more easily. While this issue was nothing disastrous, it could have greatly increased the efficiency of our work.

This course's strengths are the constant hands-on advice delivered by COL Erfourth and what you can learn from his decades of accumulated experience. This is helpful for anyone looking to work in any field.

Going forward, I think the course can improve by pruning readings and early class time so these aspects of the course have a greater impact on the final product. I would have found it helpful to be told emphatically and several times that I needed to be prepared to trade correct theory for best practice.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was no different from any other in terms of its use of technology due to the pandemic. I think Zoom was effective and we learned to use it for collaboration and discussions.

In this course, we didn't really have multiple practices that allowed for virtual engagement. Being an intimate seminar with only 6 people total, our meetings usually consisted of in-depth discussion. That being said, I actually think engagement was really high in this course because of the small size of our group.

Our class lost the opportunity to meet some really fascinating people, and that was sad. I feel like the class would have been more fun had we had the opportunity to get to know COL Erfourth more outside of class. Nothing to be done about it, though. Our classes were generally pretty great.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend the SOCOM capstone to any Global Affairs major. The client is incredibly engaging and willing to offer useful feedback to help you refine the deliverable. Furthermore, Colonel Erfourth is a gifted instructor who is deeply devoted to teaching and helping students achieve their best.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. Not only was working on this problem very gratifying because of its significance, working for a client like USSOCOM was great practice and experience for the real world. If a student is looking for an intellectual challenge, with a lot of rewarding outcomes, this is the capstone for them!

If a Capstone course with Col. Erfourth is ever offered again, I would highly recommend it. What I love about the Col is that he is a no-BS, straight shooter who genuinely cares about the learning and success of each individual student as well as the composite team. Despite that he is a formal professor, he is the best educator I have taken a class with at Yale. If you have any interest in military strategy & operations, this is the course to take. The only caveat is that taking a course with Col involves an extraordinary amount of work - reasonably equivalent to that of two separate courses - because you are both absorbing knowledge (about the military) and applying it in order to create a strategy product.

I cannot think of another Capstone project that I would have rather taken.  I learned useful things, I made great friends, and the work I did had the potential to have a significant impact on the world. Not bad for one course! All Capstones are a lot of work; not all of them mean something.
